lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: For sleeping England long time have I watch'd;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: The pleasure that some fathers feed upon,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Can sick men play so nicely with their names?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: JOHN OF GAUNT
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: No, misery makes sport to mock itself:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Should dying men flatter with those that live?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: JOHN OF GAUNT
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: JOHN OF GAUNT
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: JOHN OF GAUNT
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill.
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: And thou, too careless patient as thou art,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Of those physicians that first wounded thee:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Whose compass is no bigger than thy head;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: And yet, incaged in so small a verge,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: O, had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Deposing thee before thou wert possess'd,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Which art possess'd now to depose thyself.
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: It were a shame to let this land by lease;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: But for thy world enjoying but this land,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Is it not more than shame to shame it so?
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Landlord of England art thou now, not king:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: A lunatic lean-witted fool,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Presuming on an ague's privilege,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Darest with thy frozen admonition
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: With fury from his native residence.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Now, by my seat's right royal majesty,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: JOHN OF GAUNT
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: O, spare me not, my brother Edward's son,

lines.value: For that I was his father Edward's son;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: That blood already, like the pelican,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Whom fair befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls!
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Join with the present sickness that I have;
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: And thy unkindness be like crooked age,
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: To crop at once a too long wither'd flower.
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee!
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: These words hereafter thy tormentors be!
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Convey me to my bed, then to my grave:
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: Love they to live that love and honour have.
lines.speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And let them die that age and sullens have;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: But only they have privilege to live.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: DUKE OF YORK
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: About his marriage, nor my own disgrace,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first:
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: In war was never lion raged more fierce,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: In peace was never gentle lamb more mild,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Than was that young and princely gentleman.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: But when he frown'd, it was against the French
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: And not against his friends; his noble hand
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Did will what he did spend and spent not that
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Which his triumphant father's hand had won;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: His hands were guilty of no kindred blood,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: But bloody with the enemies of his kin.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: O Richard! York is too far gone with grief,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Or else he never would compare between.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Why, uncle, what's the matter?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: DUKE OF YORK
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: His charters and his customary rights;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Call in the letters patent that he hath
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: By his attorneys-general to sue
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: His livery, and deny his offer'd homage,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: You pluck a thousand dangers on your head,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: You lose a thousand well-disposed hearts
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: And prick my tender patience, to those thoughts
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Which honour and allegiance cannot think.

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY

lines.speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY

lines.value: LORD ROSS

lines.speaker: LORD ROSS

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: But as I come, I come for Lancaster.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: You are my father, for methinks in you
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born?
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: If that my cousin king be King of England,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Had you first died, and he been thus trod down,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: I am denied to sue my livery here,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And yet my letters-patents give me leave:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And these and all are all amiss employ'd.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: What would you have me do? I am a subject,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And therefore, personally I lay my claim
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To my inheritance of free descent.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: NORTHUMBERLAND
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: The noble duke hath been too much abused.
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: LORD ROSS
lines.speaker: LORD ROSS

lines.value: It stands your grace upon to do him right.
lines.speaker: LORD ROSS

lines.value: LORD WILLOUGHBY
lines.speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY

lines.value: Base men by his endowments are made great.
lines.speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY

lines.value: DUKE OF YORK
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: My lords of England, let me tell you this:
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: And laboured all I could to do him right;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: But in this kind to come, in braving arms,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Be his own carver and cut out his way,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: To find out right with wrong, it may not be;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: And you that do abet him in this kind
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: NORTHUMBERLAND
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: The noble duke hath sworn his coming is
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: But for his own; and for the right of that
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: We all have strongly sworn to give him aid;
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: DUKE OF YORK
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Well, well, I see the issue of these arms:
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: I cannot mend it, I must needs confess,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Because my power is weak and all ill left:
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: But if I could, by Him that gave me life,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: I would attach you all and make you stoop
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Unto the sovereign mercy of the king;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: But since I cannot, be it known to you
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: I do remain as neuter. So, fare you well;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Unless you please to enter in the castle
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: And there repose you for this night.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: An offer, uncle, that we will accept:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: But we must win your grace to go with us
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To Bristol castle, which they say is held
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: By Bushy, Bagot and their complices,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: The caterpillars of the commonwealth,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Which I have sworn to weed and pluck away.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: DUKE OF YORK
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: For I am loath to break our country's laws.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are:
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Things past redress are now with me past care.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: Captain
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: My lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days,
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: And hardly kept our countrymen together,
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: And yet we hear no tidings from the king;
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: Therefore we will disperse ourselves: farewell.
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: EARL OF SALISBURY
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman:
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Captain
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: 'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not stay.
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap,
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: The one in fear to lose what they enjoy,
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: The other to enjoy by rage and war:
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: These signs forerun the death or fall of kings.
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled,
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: As well assured Richard their king is dead.
lines.speaker: Captain

lines.value: EARL OF SALISBURY
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Ah, Richard, with the eyes of heavy mind
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: I see thy glory like a shooting star
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Fall to the base earth from the firmament.
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west,
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Witnessing storms to come, woe and unrest:
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes,
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Bring forth these men.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls--
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Since presently your souls must part your bodies--
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: With too much urging your pernicious lives,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blood
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: From off my hands, here in the view of men
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: I will unfold some causes of your deaths.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: You have misled a prince, a royal king,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: A happy gentleman in blood and lineaments,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: By you unhappied and disfigured clean:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: You have in manner with your sinful hours
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Made a divorce betwixt his queen and him,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Broke the possession of a royal bed
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And stain'd the beauty of a fair queen's cheeks
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: With tears drawn from her eyes by your foul wrongs.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Myself, a prince by fortune of my birth,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Near to the king in blood, and near in love
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Till you did make him misinterpret me,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Have stoop'd my neck under your injuries,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And sigh'd my English breath in foreign clouds,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Eating the bitter bread of banishment;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Whilst you have fed upon my signories,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Dispark'd my parks and fell'd my forest woods,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: From my own windows torn my household coat,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Razed out my imprese, leaving me no sign,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Save men's opinions and my living blood,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To show the world I am a gentleman.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: This and much more, much more than twice all this,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Condemns you to the death. See them deliver'd over
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To execution and the hand of death.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: BUSHY
lines.speaker: BUSHY

lines.value: More welcome is the stroke of death to me
lines.speaker: BUSHY

lines.value: Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords, farewell.
lines.speaker: BUSHY

lines.value: GREEN
lines.speaker: GREEN

lines.value: My comfort is that heaven will take our souls
lines.speaker: GREEN

lines.value: And plague injustice with the pains of hell.
lines.speaker: GREEN

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Uncle, you say the queen is at your house;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Tell her I send to her my kind commends;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: DUKE OF YORK
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: With letters of your love to her at large.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF YORK

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Thank, gentle uncle. Come, lords, away.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To fight with Glendower and his complices:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Awhile to work, and after holiday.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: DUKE OF AUMERLE
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: Yea, my lord. How brooks your grace the air,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: After your late tossing on the breaking seas?
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: To stand upon my kingdom once again.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: As a long-parted mother with her child
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And do thee favours with my royal hands.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Which with usurping steps do trample thee:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Guard it, I pray thee, with a lurking adder
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: This earth shall have a feeling and these stones
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: Hath power to keep you king in spite of all.
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: The means that heaven yields must be embraced,
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: And not neglected; else, if heaven would,
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse,
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: The proffer'd means of succor and redress.
lines.speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE

lines.value: DUKE OF AUMERLE
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: He means, my lord, that we are too remiss;
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security,
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: Grows strong and great in substance and in power.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: That when the searching eye of heaven is hid,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Behind the globe, that lights the lower world,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: In murders and in outrage, boldly here;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: But when from under this terrestrial ball
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And darts his light through every guilty hole,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Then murders, treasons and detested sins,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The cloak of night being pluck'd from off their backs,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Who all this while hath revell'd in the night
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Shall see us rising in our throne, the east,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: His treasons will sit blushing in his face,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Not able to endure the sight of day,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: But self-affrighted tremble at his sin.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Not all the water in the rough rude sea
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Can wash the balm off from an anointed king;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The breath of worldly men cannot depose
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The deputy elected by the Lord:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: A glorious angel: then, if angels fight,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Weak men must fall, for heaven still guards the right.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Welcome, my lord	how far off lies your power?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: EARL OF SALISBURY
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord,
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: And bids me speak of nothing but despair.
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: One day too late, I fear me, noble lord,
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth:
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: O, call back yesterday, bid time return,
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late,
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state:
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead.
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.
lines.speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY

lines.value: DUKE OF AUMERLE
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: But now the blood of twenty thousand men
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Did triumph in my face, and they are fled;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And, till so much blood thither come again,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Have I not reason to look pale and dead?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: All souls that will be safe fly from my side,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: For time hath set a blot upon my pride.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: DUKE OF AUMERLE
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.
lines.speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: I had forgot myself; am I not king?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: At thy great glory. Look not to the ground,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Ye favourites of a king: are we not high?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: More health and happiness betide my liege
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And what loss is it to be rid of care?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Greater he shall not be; if he serve God,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: They break their faith to God as well as us:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The worst is death, and death will have his day.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: To bear the tidings of calamity.
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Like an unseasonable stormy day,
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores,
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: As if the world were all dissolved to tears,
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: So high above his limits swells the rage
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices,
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Strive to speak big and clap their female joints
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown:
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows
lines.speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

lines.value: Of double-fatal yew against thy state;

lines.value: Bearing their own misfortunes on the back
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Of such as have before endured the like.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Thus play I in one person many people,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And none contented: sometimes am I king;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And so I am: then crushing penury
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Persuades me I was better when a king;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Then am I king'd again: and by and by
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And straight am nothing: but whate'er I be,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Nor I nor any man that but man is
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: With being nothing. Music do I hear?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Ha, ha! keep time: how sour sweet music is,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: When time is broke and no proportion kept!
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: So is it in the music of men's lives.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And here have I the daintiness of ear
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: But for the concord of my state and time
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Had not an ear to hear my true time broke.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: I wasted time, and now doth time waste me;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: For now hath time made me his numbering clock:
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Whereto my finger, like a dial's point,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Show minutes, times, and hours: but my time
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: This music mads me; let it sound no more;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: For though it have holp madmen to their wits,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: In me it seems it will make wise men mad.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me!
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: For 'tis a sign of love; and love to Richard
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Is a strange brooch in this all-hating world.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Groom
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: Hail, royal prince!
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Thanks, noble peer;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: What art thou? and how comest thou hither,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Where no man never comes but that sad dog
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: That brings me food to make misfortune live?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Groom
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: I was a poor groom of thy stable, king,
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York,
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: With much ado at length have gotten leave
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: O, how it yearn'd my heart when I beheld
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: In London streets, that coronation-day,
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary,
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: That horse that thou so often hast bestrid,
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: That horse that I so carefully have dress'd!
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Rode he on Barbary? Tell me, gentle friend,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: How went he under him?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Groom
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back!
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: This hand hath made him proud with clapping him.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Would he not stumble? would he not fall down,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Since pride must have a fall, and break the neck
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Of that proud man that did usurp his back?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Forgiveness, horse! why do I rail on thee,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Since thou, created to be awed by man,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Wast born to bear? I was not made a horse;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: And yet I bear a burthen like an ass,
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Spurr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Keeper
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: Fellow, give place; here is no longer stay.
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: If thou love me, 'tis time thou wert away.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Groom
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.
lines.speaker: Groom

lines.value: Keeper
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: My lord, will't please you to fall to?
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Keeper
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: lately came from the king, commands the contrary.
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee!
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Keeper
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: Help, help, help!
lines.speaker: Keeper

lines.value: KING RICHARD II
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: How now! what means death in this rude assault?
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Villain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Go thou, and fill another room in hell.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: That staggers thus my person. Exton, thy fierce hand
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Hath with the king's blood stain'd the king's own land.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Mount, mount, my soul! thy seat is up on high;
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward, here to die.
lines.speaker: KING RICHARD II

lines.value: EXTON
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: As full of valour as of royal blood:
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good!
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: For now the devil, that told me I did well,
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: Says that this deed is chronicled in hell.
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: This dead king to the living king I'll bear
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: Take hence the rest, and give them burial here.
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Kind uncle York, the latest news we hear
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Is that the rebels have consumed with fire
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Welcome, my lord	what is the news?
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: NORTHUMBERLAND
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: First, to thy sacred state wish I all happiness.
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: The next news is, I have to London sent
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: The heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt, and Kent:
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: The manner of their taking may appear
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: At large discoursed in this paper here.
lines.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: LORD FITZWATER
lines.speaker: LORD FITZWATER

lines.value: My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London
lines.speaker: LORD FITZWATER

lines.value: The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely,
lines.speaker: LORD FITZWATER

lines.value: Two of the dangerous consorted traitors
lines.speaker: LORD FITZWATER

lines.value: That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.
lines.speaker: LORD FITZWATER

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: HENRY PERCY
lines.speaker: HENRY PERCY

lines.value: The grand conspirator, Abbot of Westminster,
lines.speaker: HENRY PERCY

lines.value: With clog of conscience and sour melancholy
lines.speaker: HENRY PERCY

lines.value: Hath yielded up his body to the grave;
lines.speaker: HENRY PERCY

lines.value: But here is Carlisle living, to abide
lines.speaker: HENRY PERCY

lines.value: Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.
lines.speaker: HENRY PERCY

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Carlisle, this is your doom:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Choose out some secret place, some reverend room,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: So as thou livest in peace, die free from strife:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: For though mine enemy thou hast ever been,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: High sparks of honour in thee have I seen.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: EXTON
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: Great king, within this coffin I present
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: The mightiest of thy greatest enemies,
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: A deed of slander with thy fatal hand
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Upon my head and all this famous land.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: EXTON
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.
lines.speaker: EXTON

lines.value: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: They love not poison that do poison need,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: I hate the murderer, love him murdered.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: But neither my good word nor princely favour:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: With Cain go wander through shades of night,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And never show thy head by day nor light.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Lords, I protest, my soul is full of woe,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: Come, mourn with me for that I do lament,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: And put on sullen black incontinent:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land,
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: To wash this blood off from my guilty hand:
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: March sadly after; grace my mournings here;
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE

lines.value: In weeping after this untimely bier.
lines.speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
